captions.text:
The universe is chock-full of unanswered questions,
as you know, but a lot of them have to do

with our very own stellar neighborhood. For
example: why does Saturn have rings?

It's one of the most common questions asked
about our solar system, and while there is

no single agreed-upon answer, understanding
Saturn's rings might begin with the fact that

it's not the only planet around here that
has them. Jupiter has three very faint rings,

Neptune has five, and Uranus has thirteen.
So a better question might be: why do all
of our gas giants have rings?

To answer that, let's start with an interesting
little rule that celestial bodies tend to

abide by, know as the 'Roche limit'. First
identified by French astronomer Édouard Roche

in the 1840s, this limit is the distance at
which objects in orbit around a planet tend

to be torn apart by the planet's gravitation.
A planet pulls harder on the side of a satellite

that's facing it, so if a satellite gets too
close the unevenness of that attraction will

likely cause it to break up. And that is apparently
what happened to most of our gas giants, because

with a few exceptions their rings are almost
always inside their Roche limits, while the
moons are outside.

So in the case of Saturn's rings, one prevailing
theory is that billions of years ago some

rogue wanderer, like a comet, got swept into
orbit within Saturn's Roche limit and broke

apart. Another model suggests that a moon
that once orbited Saturn at a safe distance

got smacked by a celestial object into the
danger zone, where it disintegrated. By this

logic, then, part of the reason why gas giants
have rings might have to do with their size:

they're just so big that they're more likely
to draw in passing objects.

But their distance from the sun is important
too. While the rings of Jupiter and Neptune

are basically faint halos of dust, those around
Saturn and Uranus are bigger and made up of

almost entirely water ice, along with the
volatile organic compounds that evaporate

easily. So in addition to forming around large
planets with big Roche limits, rings might

also form more readily around planets where
it's cold enough for the icy fragments of

those crack-ups to survive. So you could say
that Saturn's rings are just beautiful remnants
of bad break-ups.

Thanks for asking, and thanks to all our Subbable
subscribers who make this and everything you

see here on SciShow possible. How'd you like
an official SciShow chocolate bar, or one

of our patented pocket protectors? To find
out how you can score these and other perks,

go to Subbable.com/SciShow, and if you have
a quick question you'd like us to answer you

can find us on Facebook and Twitter, and,
as always, in the comments below, and don't
forget to go to Youtube.com/Scishow and subscribe.

comments.text:
I'm confused. Isn't there a moon floating in the gap of saturn's rings? 
Obviously within the Roche limit. Why isn't it disintegrating? Why did you 
say planets rings are mostly within the Roche limit? How is it they would 
be outside of it? Also, if a planet has a gravitational pull what stops the 
pull from pulling an object into the Roche limit; Why aren't the moons of 
planets being pulled into their Roche limit? And lastly, Does a Roche limit 
only exist in gas planets? Thanks if u answer!﻿
comments.author: Jennie Alarid

comments.text:
+TheRABIDdude  just google it, there is a huge moon like rock orbiting 
inside Saturns rings. it could be in the process of being gradually torn 
apart over the next billion or so years.
comments.author: antifapers

comments.text:
I don't know about if there's a moon inside one of its rings, please link 
me something which says there is because that sounds interesting if it's 
true. I think he's saying that the fact that the rings are mostly inside 
the Roche limit is good because it provides evidence of the maths behind 
the Roche limit. Bits of rings outside the limit may have drifted further 
out (for whatever reason) after the parent body disintegrated. Moons aren't 
pulled into the Roche limit for the self-same reason that the Earth isn't 
sucked into the sun; they are in orbit so do not fall closer to the planet 
(although the orbit may get slightly closer/tighter over very long periods 
of time). A Roche limit does not only exist in gas planets, rather it only 
exists in planets/stars large enough to have enough mass to tear things 
apart. Rings are more common in the gas giants because their stronger 
gravitational pull is able to attract many more asteroids, so the number of 
asteroids that cross the Roche limit without hitting the planet itself 
increase.

comments.text:
you got me there, the first question on why they are orbiting the way they 
do is simple to explain, but how they got there in the first place is 
beyond me. we could speculate, simple deduction is that SOMETHING was 
moving at a highspeed and collapsed in on itself due to saturns gravity 
whyle passing by it or it could very well be that its just a collection of 
small particles that built up over time, he did say its mostly dust and ice 
wich could only be 1 of two things,a big asteroid or a big comet wich is 
possible. i would like to also point out that the planets were dust 
billions of years ago and a possible speed boost between two celestial 
object's gravity on a passing by object is what could have made said 
objects move at a high speed, move out of orbit, wonder in space in an 
undetermined path, eventually collide with saturn(maybe not directly 
collide because it would have destroyed saturn, but pass by it very 
closely), get crushed under the gravitational force, and after a few 
thousand years become the rings it now has. ... im sorry if i didnt explain 
it in a shorter way its just that there are many variables here, but non 
the less its what most likely happened,
comments.author: Jonathan Cross

comments.text:
But how did the objects begin to move at a high speed.  If millions of 
years ago planets were dust clouds, how did the chunks that became moons or 
rings gain speed?
comments.author: Martin Bradford

comments.text:
easy, the remnants more than likely were moving at a very high speed when 
destroyed and as a result the little particles are moving faster than the 
gravity can pull them towards the planet, but not fast enough so as to fly 
away. think of spinning a ball tied to a string, the faster you rotate it 
the farther it gets away from the center but the string (gravity) dosent 
let it fly away.

+Maarten De Leeuw That's exactly right. It's the same reason planets will 
orbit a star not only in a planar field but in the same direction as well. 
Billions of years of conflicting orbits and chaotic planes lead to 
trillions of collisions. Eventually, a favoured plane and direction will 
prevail.
